quizzes.title: Frontend Development Basics - Level 1
quizzes.description: Fundamental concepts of frontend development including HTML, CSS, and JavaScript basics

questions.question_text: What does HTML stand for?
questions.explanation: HTML stands for HyperText Markup Language, which is the standard markup language for creating web pages.

questions.question_text: Which CSS property is used to change the text color?
questions.explanation: The 'color' property is used to set the color of text in CSS.

questions.question_text: Which JavaScript method is used to add an element to the end of an array?
questions.explanation: The push() method adds one or more elements to the end of an array and returns the new length.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of CSS?
questions.explanation: CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is used to style and layout web pages, controlling the visual appearance.

options.text: To style and layout web pages
To add interactivity to web pages

questions.question_text: Which HTML tag is used to create a hyperlink?
questions.explanation: The <a> tag (anchor tag) is used to create hyperlinks in HTML.

questions.question_text: What does CSS stand for?
questions.explanation: CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets, used for styling HTML documents.

questions.question_text: Which JavaScript keyword is used to declare a variable that cannot be reassigned?
questions.explanation: The 'const' keyword declares a constant variable that cannot be reassigned.

questions.question_text: What is the correct HTML tag for the largest heading?
questions.explanation: The <h1> tag represents the largest/most important heading in HTML.

quizzes.title: Frontend Development Intermediate - Level 2
quizzes.description: Intermediate frontend concepts including responsive design, modern frameworks, and state management

questions.question_text: What is the virtual DOM in React?
questions.explanation: The virtual DOM is a lightweight copy of the actual DOM that React uses to optimize rendering performance.

options.text: A backup copy of the database
A lightweight copy of the actual DOM

questions.question_text: Which CSS framework is known for utility-first classes?
questions.explanation: Tailwind CSS is a utility-first CSS framework that provides low-level utility classes.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of useEffect hook in React?
questions.explanation: useEffect is used to perform side effects in functional components, such as data fetching and subscriptions.

questions.question_text: What does the Flexbox layout model primarily help with?
questions.explanation: Flexbox is a one-dimensional layout method for arranging items in rows or columns.

options.text: Arranging items in rows or columns

questions.question_text: Which method is used to make HTTP requests in modern JavaScript?
questions.explanation: The fetch() API is the modern standard for making HTTP requests in JavaScript.

questions.question_text: What is prop drilling in React?
questions.explanation: Prop drilling is passing data through multiple component layers to reach a deeply nested component.

options.text: Passing props through multiple component layers

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of React Router?
questions.explanation: React Router is a library for handling navigation and routing in React applications.

questions.question_text: What does CSS Grid provide that Flexbox doesn't?
questions.explanation: CSS Grid provides two-dimensional layout capabilities (rows and columns), while Flexbox is one-dimensional.

quizzes.title: Frontend Development Advanced - Level 3
quizzes.description: Advanced frontend topics including performance optimization, advanced patterns, and architecture

questions.question_text: What is code splitting in React?
questions.explanation: Code splitting is a technique to split your code into smaller chunks which can be loaded on demand.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of React.memo()?
questions.explanation: React.memo() is a higher-order component that memoizes a component to prevent unnecessary re-renders.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of Web Workers?
questions.explanation: Web Workers allow running scripts in background threads without blocking the UI thread.

options.text: To run scripts in background threads

questions.question_text: What is Server-Side Rendering (SSR)?
questions.explanation: SSR is rendering web pages on the server before sending them to the client, improving initial load time and SEO.

options.text: Rendering pages on the client only
Rendering pages on the server before sending to client

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of useMemo hook?
questions.explanation: useMemo memoizes expensive computations to avoid recalculating on every render.

questions.question_text: What is tree shaking in webpack?
questions.explanation: Tree shaking is the process of removing unused code from the final bundle.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of Progressive Web Apps (PWAs)?
questions.explanation: PWAs provide app-like experiences on the web with offline capability and installability.

options.text: To make web apps load progressively
To provide app-like web experiences with offline support

questions.question_text: What is the Intersection Observer API used for?
questions.explanation: Intersection Observer API provides a way to asynchronously observe changes in the intersection of a target element with an ancestor element or viewport.

quizzes.title: Frontend Development Expert - Level 4
quizzes.description: Expert-level frontend architecture, micro-frontends, and enterprise patterns

questions.question_text: What are micro-frontends?
questions.explanation: Micro-frontends extend microservice principles to frontend development, allowing teams to work independently on different parts of a web application.

options.text: Independent frontend modules in a larger application

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of Module Federation in Webpack 5?
questions.explanation: Module Federation allows sharing code and dependencies between separately built and deployed applications at runtime.

options.text: To share code between separate applications at runtime

questions.question_text: What is the Jamstack architecture?
questions.explanation: Jamstack is an architecture using JavaScript, APIs, and Markup to build fast, secure websites with pre-rendering and decoupling.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of Web Assembly (WASM)?
questions.explanation: WebAssembly is a binary instruction format that enables near-native performance for web applications.

options.text: To run code at near-native performance in browsers

questions.question_text: What is the Flux pattern in state management?
questions.explanation: Flux is an architecture pattern with unidirectional data flow, using Actions, Dispatcher, Store, and View.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of service workers?
questions.explanation: Service workers are scripts that run in the background, enabling features like offline functionality, push notifications, and background sync.

options.text: To enable offline functionality and background features

questions.question_text: What is the Island Architecture pattern?
questions.explanation: Island Architecture allows combining static and dynamic content, where interactive components (islands) exist within static HTML.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of ESBuild?
questions.explanation: ESBuild is an extremely fast JavaScript bundler and minifier written in Go.

quizzes.title: Backend Development Basics - Level 1
quizzes.description: Fundamental backend development concepts including APIs, databases, and server basics

questions.question_text: What does API stand for?
questions.explanation: API stands for Application Programming Interface, which allows different software applications to communicate.

questions.question_text: Which HTTP method is used to create a new resource?
questions.explanation: POST is the HTTP method used to create new resources on the server.

questions.question_text: What is SQL primarily used for?
questions.explanation: SQL (Structured Query Language) is used for managing and querying relational databases.

questions.question_text: What is a database?
questions.explanation: A database is an organized collection of structured data stored electronically.

options.text: An organized collection of structured data

questions.question_text: What does REST stand for in RESTful APIs?
questions.explanation: REST stands for Representational State Transfer, an architectural style for designing networked applications.

questions.question_text: Which status code indicates a successful HTTP request?
questions.explanation: Status code 200 indicates a successful HTTP request.

questions.question_text: What is JSON?
questions.explanation: JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is a lightweight data interchange format.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of a web server?
questions.explanation: A web server stores, processes, and delivers web pages to clients upon request.

options.text: To deliver web pages to clients

quizzes.title: Backend Development Intermediate - Level 2
quizzes.description: Intermediate backend concepts including authentication, middleware, and database optimization

questions.question_text: What is JWT used for?
questions.explanation: JWT (JSON Web Token) is used for securely transmitting information and authentication between parties.

questions.question_text: What is middleware in web applications?
questions.explanation: Middleware is software that sits between the request and response, processing requests before they reach the endpoint.

options.text: The middle layer of a database
Software that processes requests before endpoints

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of database indexing?
questions.explanation: Database indexing improves the speed of data retrieval operations by creating data structures for quick lookup.

questions.question_text: What is ORM?
questions.explanation: ORM (Object-Relational Mapping) is a technique that allows querying and manipulating data using object-oriented paradigm.

questions.question_text: What is CORS?
questions.explanation: CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) is a mechanism that allows restricted resources to be requested from another domain.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of environment variables?
questions.explanation: Environment variables store configuration and sensitive data outside the codebase.

questions.question_text: What is rate limiting?
questions.explanation: Rate limiting restricts the number of API requests a user can make within a time period to prevent abuse.

questions.question_text: What is a database transaction?
questions.explanation: A transaction is a sequence of database operations that are treated as a single unit of work.

options.text: A single unit of database operations

quizzes.title: Data Science Fundamentals - Level 1
quizzes.description: Introduction to data science concepts, statistics, and basic analysis

questions.question_text: What is data science?
questions.explanation: Data science is an interdisciplinary field that uses scientific methods and algorithms to extract knowledge from data.

options.text: Extracting knowledge from data using scientific methods

questions.question_text: What is the mean of a dataset?
questions.explanation: The mean is the average of all values in a dataset, calculated by summing all values and dividing by the count.

questions.question_text: What is Python primarily used for in data science?
questions.explanation: Python is widely used for data analysis, manipulation, and machine learning due to its extensive libraries.

questions.question_text: What is a dataset?
questions.explanation: A dataset is a collection of data, typically organized in tables with rows and columns.

questions.question_text: What is the median of a dataset?
questions.explanation: The median is the middle value when data is arranged in order.

options.text: The middle value when data is ordered

questions.question_text: What is data visualization?
questions.explanation: Data visualization is the graphical representation of information and data using charts, graphs, and other visual elements.

questions.question_text: What is a variable in statistics?
questions.explanation: A variable is a characteristic or attribute that can take different values across observations.

options.text: A characteristic that varies across observations

questions.question_text: What is correlation?
questions.explanation: Correlation measures the relationship between two variables and how they change together.

quizzes.title: Data Science Machine Learning - Level 2
quizzes.description: Introduction to machine learning algorithms and model training

questions.question_text: What is supervised learning?
questions.explanation: Supervised learning uses labeled data to train models to make predictions on new, unseen data.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of a training set?
questions.explanation: A training set is data used to train a machine learning model to learn patterns.

options.text: To train the model to learn patterns

questions.question_text: What is overfitting?
questions.explanation: Overfitting occurs when a model learns the training data too well, including noise, and performs poorly on new data.

options.text: Model learns training data too well including noise

questions.question_text: What is a feature in machine learning?
questions.explanation: A feature is an individual measurable property or characteristic used as input for a model.

options.text: An input variable for the model

questions.question_text: What is cross-validation?
questions.explanation: Cross-validation is a technique to assess model performance by training and testing on different subsets of data.

options.text: Training and testing on different data subsets

questions.question_text: What is regression in machine learning?
questions.explanation: Regression is predicting continuous numerical values based on input features.

questions.question_text: What is classification in machine learning?
questions.explanation: Classification is categorizing data into discrete classes or categories.

questions.question_text: What is a neural network?
questions.explanation: A neural network is a computing system inspired by biological neural networks, used for pattern recognition and learning.

options.text: A computing system inspired by biological neurons

quizzes.title: Cybersecurity Basics - Level 1
quizzes.description: Fundamental cybersecurity concepts, threats, and basic security practices

questions.question_text: What is cybersecurity?
questions.explanation: Cybersecurity is the practice of protecting systems, networks, and data from digital attacks.

options.text: Protecting systems, networks, and data from digital attacks

questions.question_text: What is a firewall?
questions.explanation: A firewall is a network security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic.

options.text: A network security system controlling traffic

questions.question_text: What is malware?
questions.explanation: Malware is malicious software designed to harm, exploit, or compromise computer systems.

options.text: Malicious software designed to harm systems

questions.question_text: What is phishing?
questions.explanation: Phishing is a cyber attack that uses fraudulent emails or websites to trick people into revealing sensitive information.

options.text: Fraudulent attempts to obtain sensitive information

questions.question_text: What does encryption do?
questions.explanation: Encryption converts data into a coded format to prevent unauthorized access.

questions.question_text: What is two-factor authentication (2FA)?
questions.explanation: 2FA is a security process requiring two different authentication factors to verify identity.

questions.question_text: What is a strong password?
questions.explanation: A strong password is long, complex, and includes a mix of letters, numbers, and special characters.

options.text: A password you can easily remember
Long password with letters, numbers, and symbols

questions.question_text: What is a virus in cybersecurity?
questions.explanation: A computer virus is malicious code that replicates itself and spreads to other programs or systems.

options.text: Malicious code that replicates and spreads

quizzes.title: Cybersecurity Intermediate - Level 2
quizzes.description: Network security, threat detection, and security protocols

questions.question_text: What is penetration testing?
questions.explanation: Penetration testing is simulating cyber attacks to identify security vulnerabilities before malicious hackers can exploit them.

questions.question_text: What is SQL injection?
questions.explanation: SQL injection is a code injection attack that exploits vulnerabilities in database queries to access or modify data.

questions.question_text: What is a VPN?
questions.explanation: A VPN (Virtual Private Network) creates a secure, encrypted connection over a less secure network.

options.text: Virtual Private Network creating secure connection

questions.question_text: What is the principle of least privilege?
questions.explanation: The principle of least privilege means giving users only the minimum access rights needed to perform their tasks.

questions.question_text: What is a DDoS attack?
questions.explanation: A DDoS (Distributed Denial of Service) attack overwhelms a system with traffic from multiple sources to make it unavailable.

options.text: Distributed Denial of Service overwhelming systems

questions.question_text: What is XSS (Cross-Site Scripting)?
questions.explanation: XSS is an attack that injects malicious scripts into trusted websites to compromise user interactions.

questions.question_text: What is a security patch?
questions.explanation: A security patch is an update released to fix vulnerabilities in software.

questions.question_text: What is social engineering?
questions.explanation: Social engineering is manipulating people into divulging confidential information or performing actions that compromise security.
